newsitem.title: USA: Borland's Kahn quites board, cuts all ties.
newsitem.headline: Borland's Kahn quites board, cuts all ties.

text.p: Borland International Inc. said Thursday its controversial founder and former chief executive, Philippe Kahn, cut all ties with the company and stepped down from the board of directors.

Kahn said he resigned from Borland, a struggling developer of computer programming languages and database, to devote more time to his two-year-old company, Starfish Software, which is developing Internet products based on the Java computer language.
Borland, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., was once the third-biggest software company behind Microsoft Corp. and Lotus Development Corp., now a unit of International Business Machines Corp..
Kahn, a French mathematician, founded Borland in 1983 when he could not get a job in Silicon Valley without proper immigration documents.

Using the popularity of its computer programming products, Borland, under Kahn, expanded its business to take on Microsoft in every niche of the software industry, including selling spreadsheets and databases.
But Microsoft and its chairman, Bill Gates, fired back by improving Microsoft's programming products and cutting prices of its business applications.
Kahn was criticised by shareholders in 1995 for spending the company's money for personal use, including the recording of a jazz album.
Faced with huge losses and redoubled competition with Microsoft, Kahn resigned as Borland's CEO in 1995 and later as chairman.
He said he still owns some Borland shares, but has no other ties to the company.
